title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: h5lite package provides simple, lightweight, user-friendly interface reading writing HDF5 files. designed R users want save load R objects (vectors, matrices, arrays) HDF5 file without needing understand low-level details HDF5 C API. guide walk common use case: simulating experimental data, saving HDF5 file along metadata, reading back analysis.

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: Think HDF5 file self-contained file system. ’s single file disk can hold organized hierarchy data. three important concepts : Groups: like folders directories. use organize data. Groups can contain groups create nested structure. Datasets: like files file system. dataset stores actual data, vector, matrix, multi-dimensional array. Every dataset resides inside group. Attributes: small, named pieces metadata can attach either groups datasets. perfect storing extra information like units, descriptions, configuration parameters. h5lite designed make working structure feel natural R user.

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: primary function writing data h5_write(). creates dataset inside HDF5 file automatically handles: Creating HDF5 file doesn’t exist. Creating parent groups needed. Overwriting existing dataset path. Let’s start writing matrix simulated sensor readings dataset. ’s ! ’ve just created HDF5 file stored matrix . Helpful Tip: Notice name "experiment_1/sensor_readings". h5lite automatically created group experiment_1 creating dataset sensor_readings inside .
code: # A 3x4 matrix of sensor data sensor_data <- matrix(rnorm(12, mean = 25, sd = 0.5), nrow = 3, ncol = 4)  h5_write(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings", sensor_data)

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: default (dtype = "auto"), h5lite automatically chooses space-efficient data type can safely store numeric data. example, small integers stored int8 uint8 instead double save space. can override specifying dtype. Let’s save integer identifiers, explicitly telling h5lite use 32-bit integer type.
code: trial_ids <- 1L:12L h5_write(file, "experiment_1/trial_ids", trial_ids, dtype = "int32")

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: write single value scalar instead array, must specify dims = NULL.
code: h5_write(file, "experiment_1/run_id", "run-abc-123", dims = NULL)

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: Now ’ve written data, see ’s file?

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: h5_ls() lists objects (groups datasets) file. default, lists everything recursively. see top-level objects, use recursive = FALSE.
code: h5_ls(file) #> [1] "experiment_1"                 "experiment_1/run_id"          #> [3] "experiment_1/sensor_readings" "experiment_1/trial_ids" h5_ls(file, recursive = FALSE) #> [1] "experiment_1"

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: can inspect dataset’s properties without reading data. useful large datasets. h5_dim() returns dimensions R’s standard, column-major order. h5_typeof() returns underlying HDF5 storage type.
code: dim(sensor_data) #> [1] 3 4 h5_dim(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings") #> [1] 3 4  h5_typeof(file, "experiment_1/trial_ids") #> [1] "int32" h5_typeof(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings") #> [1] "float64"

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: read data back R, use h5_read(). automatically handles transposing data HDF5’s row-major order R’s column-major order restores correct dimensions. Safety First: h5lite reads numeric HDF5 types (integers, floats, etc.) R’s numeric (double-precision) vectors. intentional design choice prevent integer overflow, common bug reading data systems.
code: read_sensor_data <- h5_read(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings")  print(read_sensor_data) #>          [,1]     [,2]     [,3]     [,4] #> [1,] 24.29998 24.99721 24.08909 24.85865 #> [2,] 25.12766 25.31078 24.87634 24.72315 #> [3,] 23.78137 25.57421 24.87790 25.31449  # Verify that the object is identical to the original all.equal(sensor_data, read_sensor_data) #> [1] TRUE

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: Attributes small pieces metadata attached datasets groups. perfect storing things like units, configuration parameters, version info. Let’s add attributes sensor_readings dataset. can list read attributes using h5_ls_attr() h5_read_attr().
code: # Add a scalar string attribute for units h5_write_attr(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings", "units", "celsius", dims = NULL)  # Add a numeric vector attribute for calibration coefficients h5_write_attr(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings", "calibration", c(1.02, -0.5)) h5_ls_attr(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings") #> [1] "units"       "calibration"  units <- h5_read_attr(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings", "units") print(units) #> [1] "celsius"

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: h5lite special support R’s unique data types.

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: write R factor, h5lite automatically saves native HDF5 ENUM type, preserving integer values character labels.
code: conditions <- as.factor(sample(c("control", "treatment_A", "treatment_B"), 12, replace = TRUE))  h5_write(file, "experiment_1/conditions", conditions)  # Let's check the on-disk type h5_typeof(file, "experiment_1/conditions") #> [1] "ENUM"  # Read it back - it's a perfect match! read_conditions <- h5_read(file, "experiment_1/conditions")  identical(conditions, read_conditions) #> [1] TRUE

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: store binary data, use R raw vector. stores data sequence bytes.
code: binary_blob <- as.raw(c(0xDE, 0xAD, 0xBE, 0xEF)) h5_write(file, "experiment_1/binary_config", binary_blob)  read_blob <- h5_read(file, "experiment_1/binary_config") identical(binary_blob, read_blob) #> [1] TRUE

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: h5lite follows “overwrite--default” philosophy. write existing path, old data replaced.
code: h5_read(file, "experiment_1/run_id") #> [1] "run-abc-123"  # Overwrite with a new value h5_write(file, "experiment_1/run_id", "run-xyz-987", dims = NULL)  h5_read(file, "experiment_1/run_id") #> [1] "run-xyz-987"

title: Getting Started with h5lite
text: can explicitly delete datasets, groups, attributes.
code: # Delete a single dataset h5_delete(file, "experiment_1/trial_ids")  # Delete an attribute h5_delete_attr(file, "experiment_1/sensor_readings", "calibration")  # Delete an entire group and all its contents h5_delete_group(file, "experiment_1/binary_config") # This will fail, as it's a dataset h5_create_group(file, "old_data/logs") h5_delete_group(file, "old_data")  h5_ls(file, recursive = TRUE) #> [1] "experiment_1"                 "experiment_1/conditions"      #> [3] "experiment_1/run_id"          "experiment_1/sensor_readings" # Clean up the temporary file unlink(file)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Daniel P. Smith. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Smith D (2025). h5lite: Simplified HDF5 Interface. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://cmmr.github.io/h5lite/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {h5lite: Simplified HDF5 Interface},   author = {Daniel P. Smith},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://cmmr.github.io/h5lite/}, }

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: h5lite R package provides simple lightweight interface reading writing HDF5 files. designed R users want save load common R objects (vectors, matrices, arrays, factors) HDF5 file without needing understand low-level details HDF5 library.

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: h5lite “opinionated” software prioritizes simplicity safety common use cases. handles tricky parts HDF5 automatically can focus data. Simple, R-native API: Use familiar functions like h5_read() h5_write(). need learn complex new syntax. Dimensions handled automatically. R matrices saved matrices read back matrices. Parent groups created needed (e.g., writing "group/data" works even "group" doesn’t exist). Writing existing dataset path overwrites , just like re-assigning variable. Numeric data read back double prevent integer overflow surprises. Automatic data type selection saves space default (e.g., 1:100 stored 8-bit integer). Built-, easy--use compression (compress = TRUE). Easy Installation: h5lite bundles HDF5 dependency, installation simple install.packages("h5lite"). need manage system libraries. package uses HDF5 library developed HDF Group (https://www.hdfgroup.org/).

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: can install released version h5lite CRAN:
code: install.packages("h5lite")

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: API designed simple predictable.
code: library(h5lite)  file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: Use h5_write() save R objects. automatically handles dimensions chooses efficient -disk data type.
code: # Write a vector h5_write(file, "data/vector", 1:10)  # Write an R matrix mat <- matrix(c(1.1, 2.2, 3.3, 4.4), nrow = 2, ncol = 2) h5_write(file, "data/matrix", mat)  # Write a 3D array arr <- array(1L:24L, dim = c(2, 3, 4)) h5_write(file, "data/array", arr)  # Write a scalar (dims = NULL) h5_write(file, "scalar_string", "Hello!", dims = NULL)  # Write a factor (seamlessly stored and read back) fac <- as.factor(c("a", "b", "a", "c")) h5_write(file, "factor_data", fac)  # Write a large vector with compression enabled h5_write(file, "compressed_data", 1:10000, compress = TRUE)

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: Use h5_ls() see file structure.
code: # List all objects recursively h5_ls(file, recursive = TRUE) #> "compressed_data" "data"            "data/array"      "data/matrix"     #> "data/vector"     "factor_data"     "scalar_string"    # List only the top level h5_ls(file, recursive = FALSE) #> "compressed_data" "data"            "factor_data"     "scalar_string"

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: Use h5_read() read data back R. function automatically restores correct dimensions.
code: # Read the matrix mat_in <- h5_read(file, "data/matrix") print(mat_in) #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]  1.1  3.3 #> [2,]  2.2  4.4  # Verify dimensions print(dim(mat_in)) #> 2 2  all.equal(mat, mat_in) #> TRUE

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: can easily read write metadata using attributes.
code: # Write attributes to the "data/matrix" dataset h5_write_attr(file, "data/matrix", "units", "meters", dims = NULL) h5_write_attr(file, "data/matrix", "scale", c(1.0, 1.0))  # List attributes h5_ls_attr(file, "data/matrix") #> "scale" "units"  # Read an attribute units <- h5_read_attr(file, "data/matrix", "units") print(units) #> "meters"

title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: Writing existing path automatically overwrites data. Use h5_delete* functions explicitly remove objects.
code: # Overwrite the vector h5_write(file, "data/vector", c(99, 100)) h5_read(file, "data/vector") #> 99 100  # Delete the dataset h5_delete(file, "data/vector")  # Delete the attribute h5_delete_attr(file, "data/matrix", "units")  # Delete an entire group and its contents h5_delete_group(file, "data")  h5_ls(file) #> "compressed_data" "factor_data"     "scalar_string"

what: When to Use Another HDF5 Package
title: Simplified HDF5 Interface
text: h5lite intentionally simple. need advanced control HDF5 features, use comprehensive package like rhdf5 (Bioconductor) hdf5r (CRAN). Use rhdf5 hdf5r need : - Work complex custom HDF5 data types (e.g., compound types data frames, bitfields). - fine-grained control file properties, chunking, compression filters. - Perform partial /O (.e., read write small slice large -disk dataset). Use h5lite want : - Quickly safely save R matrices, arrays, objects file. - Avoid thinking low-level details.

title: Create an HDF5 Group — h5_create_group
text: Explicitly creates new group (nested groups) HDF5 file. useful creating empty group structure.

title: Create an HDF5 Group — h5_create_group
code: h5_create_group(file, name)

title: Create an HDF5 Group — h5_create_group
text: file Path HDF5 file. name full path group create (e.g., "/g1/g2").

title: Create an HDF5 Group — h5_create_group
text: Invisibly returns NULL. function called side effects.

title: Create an HDF5 Group — h5_create_group
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  h5_create_group(file, "/my/nested/group")  # List all objects recursively to see the full structure h5_ls(file, recursive = TRUE) #> [1] "my"              "my/nested"       "my/nested/group" unlink(file)

title: Delete an HDF5 Dataset — h5_delete
text: Deletes dataset HDF5 file. function delete group.

title: Delete an HDF5 Dataset — h5_delete
code: h5_delete(file, name)

title: Delete an HDF5 Dataset — h5_delete
text: file Path HDF5 file. name full path dataset delete.

title: Delete an HDF5 Dataset — h5_delete
text: Invisibly returns NULL. function called side effects.

title: Delete an HDF5 Dataset — h5_delete
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5") h5_write(file, "dset1", 1:10) h5_write(file, "dset2", 1:5) print(h5_ls(file)) #> [1] "dset1" "dset2"  h5_delete(file, "dset1") print(h5_ls(file)) #> [1] "dset2" unlink(file)

title: Delete an HDF5 Attribute — h5_delete_attr
text: Deletes attribute object.

title: Delete an HDF5 Attribute — h5_delete_attr
code: h5_delete_attr(file, name, attribute)

title: Delete an HDF5 Attribute — h5_delete_attr
text: file Path HDF5 file. name path object (dataset group). attribute name attribute delete.

title: Delete an HDF5 Attribute — h5_delete_attr
text: Invisibly returns NULL. function called side effects.

title: Delete an HDF5 Attribute — h5_delete_attr
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5") h5_write(file, "data", 1) h5_write_attr(file, "data", "attr1", "some info") print(h5_ls_attr(file, "data")) # "attr1" #> [1] "attr1"  h5_delete_attr(file, "data", "attr1") print(h5_ls_attr(file, "data")) # character(0) #> character(0) unlink(file)

title: Delete an HDF5 Group — h5_delete_group
text: Deletes group objects contained within . function delete dataset.

title: Delete an HDF5 Group — h5_delete_group
code: h5_delete_group(file, name)

title: Delete an HDF5 Group — h5_delete_group
text: file Path HDF5 file. name full path group delete (e.g., "/g1/g2").

title: Delete an HDF5 Group — h5_delete_group
text: Invisibly returns NULL. function called side effects.

title: Delete an HDF5 Group — h5_delete_group
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5") h5_write(file, "/g1/g2/dset", 1:10) print(h5_ls(file, recursive = TRUE)) # "g1" "g1/g2" "g1/g2/dset" #> [1] "g1"         "g1/g2"      "g1/g2/dset"  h5_delete_group(file, "/g1") print(h5_ls(file, recursive = TRUE)) # character(0) #> character(0) unlink(file)

title: Get HDF5 Object Dimensions — h5_dim
text: Returns dimensions dataset integer vector. dimensions match R-style (column-major) interpretation.

title: Get HDF5 Object Dimensions — h5_dim
code: h5_dim(file, name)

title: Get HDF5 Object Dimensions — h5_dim
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name dataset.

title: Get HDF5 Object Dimensions — h5_dim
text: integer vector dimensions, integer(0) scalars.

title: Get HDF5 Object Dimensions — h5_dim
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  mat <- matrix(1:10, nrow = 2, ncol = 5) h5_write(file, "matrix", mat)  # Check dims without reading the whole dataset h5_dim(file, "matrix") # Returns c(2, 5) #> [1] 2 5  unlink(file)

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Dimensions — h5_dim_attr
text: Returns dimensions attribute.

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Dimensions — h5_dim_attr
code: h5_dim_attr(file, name, attribute)

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Dimensions — h5_dim_attr
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name object attached . attribute Name attribute.

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Dimensions — h5_dim_attr
text: integer vector dimensions, integer(0) scalars.

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Dimensions — h5_dim_attr
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5") h5_write(file, "data", 1)  h5_write_attr(file, "data", "vec_attr", 1:10) h5_dim_attr(file, "data", "vec_attr") # 10 #> [1] 10  unlink(file)

title: List HDF5 Objects — h5_ls
text: Lists names objects (datasets groups) within HDF5 file group.

title: List HDF5 Objects — h5_ls
code: h5_ls(file, name = "/", recursive = TRUE)

title: List HDF5 Objects — h5_ls
text: file Path HDF5 file. name group path start listing . Defaults root group "/". recursive TRUE (default), lists objects found recursively name. FALSE, lists immediate children name.

title: List HDF5 Objects — h5_ls
text: character vector object names. name / (default), paths relative root file. name another group, paths relative group.

title: List HDF5 Objects — h5_ls
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  # Create some nested objects h5_write(file, "g1/d1", 1) h5_write(file, "g1/g2/d2", 2)  # List recursively from the root (default) h5_ls(file) # c("g1", "g1/d1", "g1/g2", "g1/g2/d2") #> [1] "g1"       "g1/d1"    "g1/g2"    "g1/g2/d2"  # List recursively from a subgroup h5_ls(file, name = "g1") # c("d1", "g2", "g2/d2") #> [1] "d1"    "g2"    "g2/d2"  unlink(file)

title: List HDF5 Attributes — h5_ls_attr
text: Lists names attributes attached specific HDF5 object.

title: List HDF5 Attributes — h5_ls_attr
code: h5_ls_attr(file, name)

title: List HDF5 Attributes — h5_ls_attr
text: file Path HDF5 file. name path object (dataset group) query. Use "/" file's root attributes.

title: List HDF5 Attributes — h5_ls_attr
text: character vector attribute names.

what: Read a Dataset from HDF5 — h5_read
title: Read a Dataset from HDF5 — h5_read
text: Reads dataset HDF5 file returns R object.

title: Read a Dataset from HDF5 — h5_read
code: h5_read(file, name)

title: Read a Dataset from HDF5 — h5_read
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name dataset (e.g., "/data/matrix").

title: Read a Dataset from HDF5 — h5_read
text: numeric, character, factor, raw vector/array.

title: Read a Dataset from HDF5 — h5_read
text: Numeric datasets read numeric (double) prevent overflow. String datasets read character. ENUM datasets read factor. 1-byte OPAQUE datasets read raw. Dimensions preserved transposed match R's column-major order.

title: Read a Dataset from HDF5 — h5_read
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  # Write a matrix mat <- matrix(1:12, nrow = 3, ncol = 4) h5_write(file, "example_matrix", mat) # Write a factor fac <- factor(c("a", "b", "a", "c")) h5_write(file, "example_factor", fac)  # Read it back mat2 <- h5_read(file, "example_matrix") fac2 <- h5_read(file, "example_factor")  # Print and verify print(mat2) #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] #> [1,]    1    4    7   10 #> [2,]    2    5    8   11 #> [3,]    3    6    9   12 all.equal(mat, mat2) #> [1] TRUE  print(fac2) #> [1] a b a c #> Levels: a b c all.equal(fac, fac2) #> [1] TRUE  unlink(file)

what: Read an Attribute from HDF5 — h5_read_attr
title: Read an Attribute from HDF5 — h5_read_attr
text: Reads attribute associated HDF5 object (dataset group).

title: Read an Attribute from HDF5 — h5_read_attr
code: h5_read_attr(file, name, attribute)

title: Read an Attribute from HDF5 — h5_read_attr
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name object (dataset group) attribute attached . attribute Name attribute read.

title: Read an Attribute from HDF5 — h5_read_attr
text: numeric, character, factor, raw vector/array.

title: Read an Attribute from HDF5 — h5_read_attr
text: Numeric attributes read numeric (double). String attributes read character. ENUM datasets read factor. 1-byte OPAQUE attributes read raw.

title: Read an Attribute from HDF5 — h5_read_attr
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  # Create a dataset to attach attributes to h5_write(file, "dset", 1)  # Write attributes of different types h5_write_attr(file, "dset", "a_string", "some metadata") h5_write_attr(file, "dset", "a_vector", c(1.1, 2.2))  # Read them back str_attr <- h5_read_attr(file, "dset", "a_string") vec_attr <- h5_read_attr(file, "dset", "a_vector")  print(str_attr) #> [1] "some metadata" print(vec_attr) #> [1] 1.1 2.2 unlink(file)

title: Get HDF5 Object Type — h5_typeof
text: Returns low-level HDF5 storage type dataset (e.g., "INT", "FLOAT", "STRING"). allows inspecting file storage type reading data R.

title: Get HDF5 Object Type — h5_typeof
code: h5_typeof(file, name)

title: Get HDF5 Object Type — h5_typeof
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name dataset.

title: Get HDF5 Object Type — h5_typeof
text: character string representing HDF5 storage type (e.g., "float64", "int32", "STRING").

title: Get HDF5 Object Type — h5_typeof
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  # Write integers h5_write(file, "integers", 1:5) # Write doubles h5_write(file, "doubles", c(1.1, 2.2))  # Check types h5_typeof(file, "integers") # "uint8" (auto-selected) #> [1] "uint8" h5_typeof(file, "doubles")  # "float64" (auto-selected) #> [1] "float64"  unlink(file)

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Type — h5_typeof_attr
text: Returns low-level HDF5 storage type attribute.

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Type — h5_typeof_attr
code: h5_typeof_attr(file, name, attribute)

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Type — h5_typeof_attr
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name object attached . attribute Name attribute.

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Type — h5_typeof_attr
text: character string representing HDF5 storage type.

title: Get HDF5 Attribute Type — h5_typeof_attr
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5") h5_write(file, "data", 1)  h5_write_attr(file, "data", "meta", "info", dims = NULL) h5_typeof_attr(file, "data", "meta") # "STRING" #> [1] "STRING"  unlink(file)

what: Write a Dataset to HDF5 — h5_write
title: Write a Dataset to HDF5 — h5_write
text: Writes R object HDF5 file dataset. file created exist. Handles dimension transposition automatically.

title: Write a Dataset to HDF5 — h5_write
code: h5_write(   file,   name,   data,   dtype = "auto",   dims = length(data),   compress = TRUE )

title: Write a Dataset to HDF5 — h5_write
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name dataset (e.g., "/data/matrix"). data R object write. Supported: numeric, integer, logical, character, raw. dtype target HDF5 data type. Defaults typeof(data). dims integer vector specifying dimensions, NULL scalar. Defaults dim(data) exists, length(data) otherwise. compress logical integer 0-9. TRUE, compression level 5 used. FALSE 0, compression used. integer 1-9 specifies zlib compression level directly.

title: Write a Dataset to HDF5 — h5_write
text: Invisibly returns NULL. function called side effects.

title: Write a Dataset to HDF5 — h5_write
text: dtype argument controls -disk storage type numeric data . dtype set "auto" (default), h5lite automatically select space-efficient type numeric data can safely represent full range values. example, writing 1:100 result 8-bit unsigned integer (uint8) dataset, helps minimize file size. override numeric data, can specify exact type. input case-insensitive allows unambiguous partial matching. full list supported values : "auto", "float", "double" "float16", "float32", "float64" "int8", "int16", "int32", "int64" "uint8", "uint16", "uint32", "uint64" "char", "short", "int", "long", "llong" "uchar", "ushort", "uint", "ulong", "ullong" Note: Types without bit-width suffix (e.g., "int", "long") system- dependent may different sizes different machines. maximum file portability, recommended use types explicit widths (e.g., "int32"). non-numeric data (character, factor, raw, logical), storage type determined automatically changed dtype argument. R logical vectors stored 8-bit unsigned integers (uint8), HDF5 native boolean datatype.

title: Write a Dataset to HDF5 — h5_write
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  # Write a simple vector (dtype is auto-detected as uint8) h5_write(file, "vec1", 1:20) h5_typeof(file, "vec1") # "uint8" #> [1] "uint8"  # Write a matrix, letting h5_write determine dimensions mat <- matrix(rnorm(12), nrow = 4, ncol = 3) h5_write(file, "group/mat", mat) h5_dim(file, "group/mat") # c(4, 3) #> [1] 4 3  # Overwrite the first vector, forcing a 32-bit integer type h5_write(file, "vec1", 101:120, dtype = "int32") h5_typeof(file, "vec1") # "int32" #> [1] "int32"  # Write a scalar value h5_write(file, "scalar", 3.14, dims = NULL)  unlink(file)

what: Write an Attribute to HDF5 — h5_write_attr
title: Write an Attribute to HDF5 — h5_write_attr
text: Writes R object attribute existing HDF5 object.

title: Write an Attribute to HDF5 — h5_write_attr
code: h5_write_attr(file, name, attribute, data, dtype = "auto", dims = length(data))

title: Write an Attribute to HDF5 — h5_write_attr
text: file Path HDF5 file. name Name object attach attribute (e.g., "/data"). attribute name attribute create. data R object write. Supported: numeric, integer, logical, character, raw. dtype target HDF5 data type. Defaults typeof(data). dims integer vector specifying dimensions, NULL scalar. Defaults dim(data) length(data).

title: Write an Attribute to HDF5 — h5_write_attr
text: Invisibly returns NULL. function called side effects.

title: Write an Attribute to HDF5 — h5_write_attr
text: dtype argument controls -disk storage type numeric data . dtype set "auto" (default), h5lite automatically select space-efficient type numeric data can safely represent full range values. example, writing 1:100 result 8-bit unsigned integer (uint8) attribute. override numeric data, can specify exact type. input case-insensitive allows unambiguous partial matching. full list supported values : "auto", "float", "double" "float16", "float32", "float64" "int8", "int16", "int32", "int64" "uint8", "uint16", "uint32", "uint64" "char", "short", "int", "long", "llong" "uchar", "ushort", "uint", "ulong", "ullong" Note: Types without bit-width suffix (e.g., "int", "long") system- dependent may different sizes different machines. maximum file portability, recommended use types explicit widths (e.g., "int32"). non-numeric data (character, factor, raw, logical), storage type determined automatically changed dtype argument. R logical vectors stored 8-bit unsigned integers (uint8), HDF5 native boolean datatype.

title: Write an Attribute to HDF5 — h5_write_attr
code: file <- tempfile(fileext = ".h5")  # First, create an object to attach attributes to h5_write(file, "my_data", 1:10)  # Write a scalar string attribute h5_write_attr(file, "my_data", "units", "meters", dims = NULL)  # Write a numeric vector attribute h5_write_attr(file, "my_data", "range", c(0, 100))  # List attributes to confirm they were written h5_ls_attr(file, "my_data") #> [1] "units" "range"  unlink(file)

what: h5lite: A Simple and Lightweight HDF5 Interface — h5lite-package
title: h5lite: A Simple and Lightweight HDF5 Interface — h5lite-package
text: h5lite package provides simple, lightweight, user-friendly interface reading writing HDF5 files. designed R users want save load R objects (vectors, matrices, arrays) HDF5 file without needing understand low-level details HDF5 C API.

title: h5lite: A Simple and Lightweight HDF5 Interface — h5lite-package
text: h5lite handles common tasks automatically: Saving R objects correct dimensions. Reading data back R matrices arrays. Reading writing R factor objects native HDF5 ENUM types. Automatically overwriting data creating parent groups. Writing compressed datasets. Safely reading numeric types without integer overflow. Reading writing R raw vectors. package uses HDF5 library developed HDF Group (https://www.hdfgroup.org/).

title: h5lite: A Simple and Lightweight HDF5 Interface — h5lite-package
text: Maintainer: Daniel P. Smith dansmith01@gmail.com
